description: Connects a Kubernetes cluster to the Amazon EKS control plane. Any Kubernetes cluster can be connected to the Amazon EKS control plane to view current information about the cluster and its nodes. Cluster connection requires two steps. First, send a RegisterClusterRequest to add it to the Amazon EKS control plane. Second, a Manifest containing the activationID and activationCode must be applied to the Kubernetes cluster through it's native provider to provide visibility. After the manifest is updated and applied, the connected cluster is visible to the Amazon EKS control plane. If the manifest isn't applied within three days, the connected cluster will no longer be visible and must be deregistered using DeregisterCluster.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: A unique name for this cluster in your Amazon Web Services Region.

parameters.name: connectorConfig
parameters.description: The configuration settings required to connect the Kubernetes cluster to the Amazon EKS control plane. The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the role that is authorized to request the connector configuration. The cloud provider for the target cluster to connect.

nested_params.name: roleArn
nested_params.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the role that is authorized to request the connector configuration.

nested_params.name: provider
nested_params.description: The cloud provider for the target cluster to connect.

parameters.name: clientRequestToken
parameters.description: A unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. This field is autopopulated if not provided.

parameters.name: tags
parameters.description: Metadata that assists with categorization and organization. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value. You define both. Tags don't propagate to any other cluster or Amazon Web Services resources. (string) --- One part of a key-value pair that make up a tag. A key is a general label that acts like a category for more specific tag values. (string) --- The optional part of a key-value pair that make up a tag. A value acts as a descriptor within a tag category (key).

nested_items.name: name
nested_items.description: The name of your cluster.

nested_items.name: arn
nested_items.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the cluster.

nested_items.name: createdAt
nested_items.description: The Unix epoch timestamp at object creation.

nested_items.name: version
nested_items.description: The Kubernetes server version for the cluster.

nested_items.name: endpoint
nested_items.description: The endpoint for your Kubernetes API server.

nested_items.name: roleArn
nested_items.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that provides permissions for the Kubernetes control plane to make calls to Amazon Web Services API operations on your behalf.

nested_items.name: resourcesVpcConfig
nested_items.description: The VPC configuration used by the cluster control plane. Amazon EKS VPC resources have specific requirements to work properly with Kubernetes. For more information, see Cluster VPC considerations and Cluster security group considerations in the Amazon EKS User Guide.

nested_items.name: subnetIds
nested_items.description: The subnets associated with your cluster.
(string) ---

nested_items.name: securityGroupIds
nested_items.description: The security groups associated with the cross-account elastic network interfaces that are used to allow communication between your nodes and the Kubernetes control plane.
(string) ---

nested_items.name: clusterSecurityGroupId
nested_items.description: The cluster security group that was created by Amazon EKS for the cluster. Managed node groups use this security group for control-plane-to-data-plane communication.

nested_items.name: vpcId
nested_items.description: The VPC associated with your cluster.

nested_items.name: endpointPublicAccess
nested_items.description: Whether the public API server endpoint is enabled.

nested_items.name: endpointPrivateAccess
nested_items.description: This parameter indicates whether the Amazon EKS private API server endpoint is enabled. If the Amazon EKS private API server endpoint is enabled, Kubernetes API requests that originate from within your cluster's VPC use the private VPC endpoint instead of traversing the internet. If this value is disabled and you have nodes or Fargate pods in the cluster, then ensure that publicAccessCidrs includes the necessary CIDR blocks for communication with the nodes or Fargate pods. For more information, see Amazon EKS cluster endpoint access control in the Amazon EKS User Guide .

nested_items.name: publicAccessCidrs
nested_items.description: The CIDR blocks that are allowed access to your cluster's public Kubernetes API server endpoint.
(string) ---

nested_items.name: kubernetesNetworkConfig
nested_items.description: The Kubernetes network configuration for the cluster.

nested_items.name: serviceIpv4Cidr
nested_items.description: The CIDR block that Kubernetes Pod and Service object IP addresses are assigned from. Kubernetes assigns addresses from an IPv4 CIDR block assigned to a subnet that the node is in. If you didn't specify a CIDR block when you created the cluster, then Kubernetes assigns addresses from either the 10.100.0.0/16 or 172.20.0.0/16 CIDR blocks. If this was specified, then it was specified when the cluster was created and it can't be changed.

nested_items.name: serviceIpv6Cidr
nested_items.description: The CIDR block that Kubernetes pod and service IP addresses are assigned from if you created a 1.21 or later cluster with version 1.10.1 or later of the Amazon VPC CNI add-on and specified ipv6 for ipFamily when you created the cluster. Kubernetes assigns service addresses from the unique local address range ( fc00::/7) because you can't specify a custom IPv6 CIDR block when you create the cluster.

nested_items.name: ipFamily
nested_items.description: The IP family used to assign Kubernetes Pod and Service objects IP addresses. The IP family is always ipv4, unless you have a 1.21 or later cluster running version 1.10.1 or later of the Amazon VPC CNI plugin for Kubernetes and specified ipv6 when you created the cluster.

nested_items.name: elasticLoadBalancing
nested_items.description: Indicates the current configuration of the load balancing capability on your EKS Auto Mode cluster. For example, if the capability is enabled or disabled.

nested_items.name: enabled
nested_items.description: Indicates if the load balancing capability is enabled on your EKS Auto Mode cluster. If the load balancing capability is enabled, EKS Auto Mode will create and delete load balancers in your Amazon Web Services account.

nested_items.name: clusterLogging
nested_items.description: The cluster control plane logging configuration for your cluster.

nested_items.name: types
nested_items.description: The available cluster control plane log types.
(string) ---

nested_items.name: enabled
nested_items.description: If a log type is enabled, that log type exports its control plane logs to CloudWatch Logs . If a log type isn't enabled, that log type doesn't export its control plane logs. Each individual log type can be enabled or disabled independently.

nested_items.name: issuer
nested_items.description: The issuer URL for the OIDC identity provider.

nested_items.name: status
nested_items.description: The current status of the cluster.

nested_items.name: certificateAuthority
nested_items.description: The certificate-authority-data for your cluster.

nested_items.name: data
nested_items.description: The Base64-encoded certificate data required to communicate with your cluster. Add this to the certificate-authority-data section of the kubeconfig file for your cluster.

nested_items.name: clientRequestToken
nested_items.description: A unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request.

nested_items.name: platformVersion
nested_items.description: The platform version of your Amazon EKS cluster. For more information about clusters deployed on the Amazon Web Services Cloud, see Platform versions in the Amazon EKS User Guide . For more information about local clusters deployed on an Outpost, see Amazon EKS local cluster platform versions in the Amazon EKS User Guide .
(string) ---
(string) ---

nested_items.name: encryptionConfig
nested_items.description: The encryption configuration for the cluster.

nested_items.name: resources
nested_items.description: Specifies the resources to be encrypted. The only supported value is secrets.
(string) ---

nested_items.name: keyArn
nested_items.description: Amazon Resource Name (ARN) or alias of the KMS key. The KMS key must be symmetric and created in the same Amazon Web Services Region as the cluster. If the KMS key was created in a different account, the IAM principal must have access to the KMS key. For more information, see Allowing users in other accounts to use a KMS key in the Key Management Service Developer Guide.

nested_items.name: connectorConfig
nested_items.description: The configuration used to connect to a cluster for registration.

nested_items.name: activationId
nested_items.description: A unique ID associated with the cluster for registration purposes.

nested_items.name: activationCode
nested_items.description: A unique code associated with the cluster for registration purposes.

nested_items.name: activationExpiry
nested_items.description: The expiration time of the connected cluster. The cluster's YAML file must be applied through the native provider.

nested_items.name: provider
nested_items.description: The cluster's cloud service provider.

nested_items.name: roleArn
nested_items.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the role to communicate with services from the connected Kubernetes cluster.

nested_items.name: id
nested_items.description: The ID of your local Amazon EKS cluster on an Amazon Web Services Outpost. This property isn't available for an Amazon EKS cluster on the Amazon Web Services cloud.

nested_items.name: issues
nested_items.description: An object representing the health issues of your Amazon EKS cluster.

nested_items.name: code
nested_items.description: The error code of the issue.

nested_items.name: message
nested_items.description: A description of the issue.

nested_items.name: resourceIds
nested_items.description: The resource IDs that the issue relates to.
(string) ---

nested_items.name: outpostConfig
nested_items.description: An object representing the configuration of your local Amazon EKS cluster on an Amazon Web Services Outpost. This object isn't available for clusters on the Amazon Web Services cloud.

nested_items.name: outpostArns
nested_items.description: The ARN of the Outpost that you specified for use with your local Amazon EKS cluster on Outposts.
(string) ---

nested_items.name: controlPlaneInstanceType
nested_items.description: The Amazon EC2 instance type used for the control plane. The instance type is the same for all control plane instances.

nested_items.name: controlPlanePlacement
nested_items.description: An object representing the placement configuration for all the control plane instances of your local Amazon EKS cluster on an Amazon Web Services Outpost. For more information, see Capacity considerations in the Amazon EKS User Guide.

nested_items.name: groupName
nested_items.description: The name of the placement group for the Kubernetes control plane instances.

nested_items.name: accessConfig
nested_items.description: The access configuration for the cluster.

nested_items.name: bootstrapClusterCreatorAdminPermissions
nested_items.description: Specifies whether or not the cluster creator IAM principal was set as a cluster admin access entry during cluster creation time.

nested_items.name: authenticationMode
nested_items.description: The current authentication mode of the cluster.

nested_items.name: upgradePolicy
nested_items.description: This value indicates if extended support is enabled or disabled for the cluster.

nested_items.name: supportType
nested_items.description: If the cluster is set to EXTENDED, it will enter extended support at the end of standard support. If the cluster is set to STANDARD, it will be automatically upgraded at the end of standard support.

nested_items.name: zonalShiftConfig
nested_items.description: The configuration for zonal shift for the cluster.

nested_items.name: enabled
nested_items.description: Whether the zonal shift is enabled.

nested_items.name: remoteNetworkConfig
nested_items.description: The configuration in the cluster for EKS Hybrid Nodes. You can add, change, or remove this configuration after the cluster is created.

nested_items.name: remoteNodeNetworks
nested_items.description: The list of network CIDRs that can contain hybrid nodes.
Each block must be within an IPv4 RFC-1918 network range. Minimum allowed size is /24, maximum allowed size is /8. Publicly-routable addresses aren't supported.
Each block cannot overlap with the range of the VPC CIDR blocks for your EKS resources, or the block of the Kubernetes service IP range.
Each block must have a route to the VPC that uses the VPC CIDR blocks, not public IPs or Elastic IPs. There are many options including Transit Gateway, Site-to-Site VPN, or Direct Connect.
Each host must allow outbound connection to the EKS cluster control plane on TCP ports 443 and 10250.
Each host must allow inbound connection from the EKS cluster control plane on TCP port 10250 for logs, exec and port-forward operations.
Each host must allow TCP and UDP network connectivity to and from other hosts that are running CoreDNS on UDP port 53 for service and pod DNS names.

nested_items.name: remotePodNetworks
nested_items.description: The list of network CIDRs that can contain pods that run Kubernetes webhooks on hybrid nodes.
Each block must be within an IPv4 RFC-1918 network range. Minimum allowed size is /24, maximum allowed size is /8. Publicly-routable addresses aren't supported.
Each block cannot overlap with the range of the VPC CIDR blocks for your EKS resources, or the block of the Kubernetes service IP range.

nested_items.name: computeConfig
nested_items.description: Indicates the current configuration of the compute capability on your EKS Auto Mode cluster. For example, if the capability is enabled or disabled. If the compute capability is enabled, EKS Auto Mode will create and delete EC2 Managed Instances in your Amazon Web Services account. For more information, see EKS Auto Mode compute capability in the Amazon EKS User Guide.

nested_items.name: enabled
nested_items.description: Indicates if the compute capability is enabled on your EKS Auto Mode cluster. If the compute capability is enabled, EKS Auto Mode will create and delete EC2 Managed Instances in your Amazon Web Services account.

nested_items.name: nodePools
nested_items.description: Indicates the current configuration of node pools in your EKS Auto Mode cluster. For more information, see EKS Auto Mode Node Pools in the Amazon EKS User Guide.
(string) ---

nested_items.name: nodeRoleArn
nested_items.description: The ARN of the IAM Role EKS will assign to EC2 Managed Instances in your EKS Auto Mode cluster.

nested_items.name: storageConfig
nested_items.description: Indicates the current configuration of the block storage capability on your EKS Auto Mode cluster. For example, if the capability is enabled or disabled. If the block storage capability is enabled, EKS Auto Mode will create and delete EBS volumes in your Amazon Web Services account. For more information, see EKS Auto Mode block storage capability in the Amazon EKS User Guide.

nested_items.name: blockStorage
nested_items.description: Indicates the current configuration of the block storage capability on your EKS Auto Mode cluster. For example, if the capability is enabled or disabled.

nested_items.name: enabled
nested_items.description: Indicates if the block storage capability is enabled on your EKS Auto Mode cluster. If the block storage capability is enabled, EKS Auto Mode will create and delete EBS volumes in your Amazon Web Services account.
